segment.source: Microsoft network server Server SPN target name validation level (Windows 10)
segment.target: Microsoft network server Server SPN target name validation level (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, and values, policy management and security considerations for the Microsoft network server Server SPN target name validation level security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, and values, policy management and security considerations for the Microsoft network server Server SPN target name validation level security policy setting.

segment.source: Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level
segment.target: Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, and values, policy management and security considerations for the Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, and values, policy management and security considerations for the Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting controls the level of validation that a server with shared folders or printers performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client device establishes a session by using the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol.
segment.target: This policy setting controls the level of validation that a server with shared folders or printers performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client device establishes a session by using the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol.

segment.source: The level of validation can help prevent a class of attacks against SMB services (referred to as SMB relay attacks).
segment.target: The level of validation can help prevent a class of attacks against SMB services (referred to as SMB relay attacks).

segment.source: This setting affects both SMB1 and SMB2.
segment.target: This setting affects both SMB1 and SMB2.

segment.source: Servers that use SMB provide availability to their file systems and other resources, such as printers, to networked client devices.
segment.target: Servers that use SMB provide availability to their file systems and other resources, such as printers, to networked client devices.

segment.source: Most servers that use SMB validate user access to resources by using NT Domain authentication (NTLMv1 and NTLMv2) and the Kerberos protocol.
segment.target: Most servers that use SMB validate user access to resources by using NT Domain authentication (NTLMv1 and NTLMv2) and the Kerberos protocol.

segment.source: The options for validation levels are:
segment.target: The options for validation levels are:

segment.source: The SPN from a SMB client is not required or validated by the SMB server.
segment.target: The SPN from a SMB client is not required or validated by the SMB server.

segment.source: The SMB server will accept and validate the SPN provided by the SMB client and allow a session to be established if it matches the SMB server’s list of SPN’s.
segment.target: The SMB server will accept and validate the SPN provided by the SMB client and allow a session to be established if it matches the SMB server’s list of SPN’s.

segment.source: If the SPN does not match, the session request for that SMB client will be denied.
segment.target: If the SPN does not match, the session request for that SMB client will be denied.

segment.source: The SMB client must send a SPN name in session setup, and the SPN name provided must match the SMB server that is being requested to establish a connection.
segment.target: The SMB client must send a SPN name in session setup, and the SPN name provided must match the SMB server that is being requested to establish a connection.

segment.source: If no SPN is provided by the client device, or the SPN provided does not match, the session is denied.
segment.target: If no SPN is provided by the client device, or the SPN provided does not match, the session is denied.

segment.source: This setting affects the server SMB behavior, and its implementation should be carefully evaluated and tested to prevent disruptions to file and print serving capabilities.
segment.target: This setting affects the server SMB behavior, and its implementation should be carefully evaluated and tested to prevent disruptions to file and print serving capabilities.

segment.source: Note: All Windows operating systems support a client-side SMB component and a server-side SMB component.
segment.target: Note: All Windows operating systems support a client-side SMB component and a server-side SMB component.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.target: Server type or Group Policy object (GPO)

segment.source: Effective GPO default settings on client computers
segment.target: Effective GPO default settings on client computers

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: This policy setting controls the level of validation that a server with shared folders or printers performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client device establishes a session by using the SMB protocol.
segment.target: This policy setting controls the level of validation that a server with shared folders or printers performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client device establishes a session by using the SMB protocol.

segment.source: The level of validation can help prevent a class of attacks against SMB servers (referred to as SMB relay attacks).
segment.target: The level of validation can help prevent a class of attacks against SMB servers (referred to as SMB relay attacks).

segment.source: This setting will affect both SMB1 and SMB2.
segment.target: This setting will affect both SMB1 and SMB2.

segment.source: For countermeasures that are appropriate to your environment, see Possible values above.
segment.target: For countermeasures that are appropriate to your environment, see Possible values above.

segment.source: All Windows operating systems support a client-side SMB component and a server-side SMB component.
segment.target: All Windows operating systems support a client-side SMB component and a server-side SMB component.

segment.source: This setting affects the server SMB behavior, and its implementation should be carefully evaluated and tested to prevent disruptions to file and print serving capabilities.
segment.target: This setting affects the server SMB behavior, and its implementation should be carefully evaluated and tested to prevent disruptions to file and print serving capabilities.

segment.source: Because the SMB protocol is widely deployed, setting the options to Accept if provided by client or Required from client will prevent some clients from successfully authenticating to some servers in your environment.
segment.target: Because the SMB protocol is widely deployed, setting the options to Accept if provided by client or Required from client will prevent some clients from successfully authenticating to some servers in your environment.
